para.text: Purpose. To protect surface water quality, this State shall adopt water quality standards to:
Protect public health or welfare;
Enhance the quality of water;
Protect aquatic resources; and
Serve the purposes of the Federal Act.
Water Quality Standards.
The surface water quality standards consist of three parts:
Designated uses of the waters of this State;
Water quality criteria to protect the designated uses; and
Antidegradation Policy.
Water quality standards shall provide water quality for the designated uses of:
Water contact recreation;
Fishing;
Propagation of fish, other aquatic life, and wildlife; and
Agricultural and industrial water supply.
Waters of this State shall be protected for the basic designated uses in Regulation .02A.
Water quality standards shall consider the use and value of public water supplies.
Regulations .02—.08 of this chapter implement this State's water quality standards by:
Defining and establishing specific designated uses for the surface waters of this State;
Assigning a designated use to all surface waters;
Establishing water quality criteria for each designated use;
Defining this State's antidegradation policy;
Defining this State's criteria for mixing zones; and
Defining other water quality protective policies.
General.
The determination of the designated use of a water body shall include consideration of the following factors:
Existing conditions; and
Potential uses which may be made possible by anticipated improvements in water quality.

The actual uses of surface water are not limited to those designated in this chapter. Any reasonable and lawful use is permitted provided that the surface water quality is not adversely affected by the use.
Specific Designated Use Classes.
Class I: Water Contact Recreation, and Protection of Nontidal Warmwater Aquatic Life. This class designation includes waters that are suitable for:
Water contact sports;
Play and leisure time activities where individuals may come in direct contact with the surface water;
Fishing;
The growth and propagation of fish (other than trout), other aquatic life, and wildlife;
Agricultural water supply; and
Industrial water supply.
Class I-P: Water Contact Recreation, Protection of Aquatic Life, and Public Water Supply. This class designation includes:
All uses identified for Class I; and
Use as a public water supply.
Class II: Support of Estuarine and Marine Aquatic Life and Shellfish Harvesting. This class designation includes all applicable uses identified for Class I in:
All tidally influenced waters of the Chesapeake Bay and tributaries, the Coastal Bays, and the Atlantic Ocean to the 3-nautical-mile boundary; and
Tidally influenced waters that are or have the potential for:
Shellfish propagation and storage, or harvest for marketing purposes; and
Actual or potential areas for the harvesting of oysters, soft-shell clams, hard-shell clams, and brackish water clams.
Class II-P: Tidal Fresh Water Estuary. This class designation includes:
All uses identified for Class II waters; and
Use as a public water supply.

Class III: Nontidal Cold Water. This class designation includes all uses identified for Class I and waters which have the potential for or are suitable for the growth and propagation of self-sustaining trout populations and other coldwater obligate species including, but not limited to the stoneflies tallaperla and sweltsa.
Class III-P: Nontidal Cold Water and Public Water Supply. This class designation includes:
All uses identified for Class III waters; and
Use as a public water supply.
Class IV: Recreational Trout Waters. This class designation includes all uses identified for Class I in cold or warm waters that have the potential for or are:
Capable of holding or supporting adult trout for put-and-take fishing; and
Managed as a special fishery by periodic stocking and seasonal catching.
Class IV-P: Recreational Trout Waters and Public Water Supply. This class designation includes:
All uses identified for Class IV waters; and
Use as a public water supply.

section.heading: Support of Estuarine and Marine Aquatic Life and Shellfish Harvesting.

para.text: Class II includes the subcategories of designated uses described in this section.
Shellfish Harvesting. This subcategory includes waters where there are:
Actual or potential areas for the harvesting of oysters, soft-shell clams, hard-shell clams, or brackish water clams; or

Actual or potential areas suitable for the propagation or storage of oysters, hard-shell clams, soft-shell clams, and brackish water clams for marketing purposes, except areas excluded by the Department.

Seasonal Migratory Fish Spawning and Nursery Subcategory. This subcategory includes waters of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries that have the potential for or are supporting the survival, growth, and propagation of balanced indigenous populations of ecologically, recreationally, and commercially important anadromous, semi-anadromous and tidal-fresh resident fish species inhabiting spawning and nursery grounds from February 1 through May 31.
Seasonal Shallow-Water Submerged Aquatic Vegetation Subcategory. This subcategory includes:

Tidal fresh waters of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries that have the potential for or are supporting the survival, growth, and propagation of rooted, underwater bay grasses in tidally influenced waters from April 1 through October 1; and

Low salinity (oligohaline and mesohaline) waters of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries that have the potential for or are supporting the survival, growth, and propagation of rooted, underwater bay grasses in tidally influenced waters from April 1 through October 1.
Open-Water Fish and Shellfish Subcategory.

This subcategory includes waters of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries that have the potential for or are supporting the survival, growth, and propagation of balanced, indigenous populations of ecologically, recreationally, and commercially important fish and shellfish species inhabiting open-water habitats.

This subcategory applies from June 1 to September 30 in tidally influenced waters from the shoreline to the adjacent shoreline (and from the shoreline to the opposite shoreline), and from the surface to the measured boundary of the pycnocline, if the pycnocline prevents oxygen replenishment, otherwise the subcategory is applied from the surface to the bottom.

If a pycnocline exists but other physical circulation patterns, such as the inflow of oxygen-rich oceanic bottom waters, provide oxygen replenishment to the deep waters, the open-water fish and shellfish designated use extends to the bottom.

From October 1 through May 31, the boundaries of the open-water designated use include all tidally influenced waters from the shoreline measured from the shoreline to the adjacent or opposite shoreline and down to the bottom.

Seasonal Deep-Water Fish and Shellfish Subcategory. This subcategory includes waters of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries that have the potential for or are supporting the survival, growth, and propagation of balanced, indigenous populations of important fish and shellfish species inhabiting deep-water habitats as described as follows:
One of the following applies:

From June 1 through September 30 in tidally influenced waters located between the measured depths of the upper and lower boundaries of the pycnocline, where a pycnocline is present and presents a barrier to oxygen replenishment; or

From June 1 through September 30 from the upper boundary of the pycnocline down to the sediment/water interface at the bottom, where a lower boundary of the pycnocline cannot be calculated due to the depth of the water column; and
From October 1 to May 31, the open water fish and shellfish subcategory designated use applies.
Seasonal Deep-Channel Refuge Use.

This subcategory includes waters of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries that have the potential for or are supporting the survival of balanced, indigenous populations of ecologically important benthic infaunal and epifaunal worms and clams, which provide food for bottom-feeding fish and crabs.

This subcategory applies from June 1 through September 30 in tidally influenced waters located below the measured lower boundary of the pycnocline to the bottom where a measured pycnocline is present and presents a barrier to oxygen replenishment.
From October 1 to May 31, the open water fish and shellfish subcategory designated use applies.
Applicability.
Surface water quality criteria shall apply:
In fresh water streams and rivers:
For toxic substances, under the conditions stipulated in Regulations .03-2A and .05A, and
Under design stream flow for all other substances;
In tidal waters:
For toxic substances, under the conditions stipulated in Regulations .03-2A and .05A, and
Under average tidal conditions during design stream flows for all other substances;
Outside of any mixing zones which may be designated by the Department.
If the natural water quality of a stream segment is not consistent with the criteria established for the stream then:
The natural conditions do not constitute a violation of the water quality standards; and
The water quality to be maintained and achieved is not required to be substantially different from that which would occur naturally.

When coal remining permits are issued under §301 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (33 U.S.C. §1311), a variance to the specific water quality criteria for pH, iron, and manganese in the State's water quality standards may be given at the discretion of the Department for the duration of the remining activity. This variance may not be given if there is no demonstrated potential for improved water quality from the remining operation and if degradation of existing in-stream conditions is likely to occur.
General Water Quality Criteria. The waters of this State may not be polluted by:
Substances attributable to sewage, industrial waste, or other waste that will settle to form sludge deposits that:
Are unsightly, putrescent, or odorous, and create a nuisance, or
Interfere directly or indirectly with designated uses;
Any material, including floating debris, oil, grease, scum, sludge, and other floating materials attributable to sewage, industrial waste, or other waste in amounts sufficient to:
Be unsightly;
Produce taste or odor;
Change the existing color to produce objectionable color for aesthetic purposes;
Create a nuisance; or
Interfere directly or indirectly with designated uses;
High temperature or corrosive substances attributable to sewage, industrial waste, or other waste in concentrations or combinations which:
Interfere directly or indirectly with designated uses, or
Are harmful to human, animal, plant, or aquatic life;
Acute toxicity from any discharge outside the mixing zone established under Regulation .05 of this chapter for the application of acute criteria for protection of aquatic life; and
Toxic substances attributable to sewage, industrial wastes, or other wastes in concentrations outside designated mixing zones, which:
Interfere directly or indirectly with designated uses, or
Are harmful to human, plant, or aquatic life.

section.heading: Toxic Substance Water Quality Criteria for Surface Waters.

para.text: General.
Numerical toxic substance criteria for ambient surface waters are established to protect human health or aquatic life.
Four types of numerical toxic substance criteria shall be adopted. The purpose of these criteria is to protect:
Human health through ingestion of public water supplies;
The wholesomeness of fish for human consumption;
Fresh, estuarine, and salt water aquatic life from acute toxicity impacts; and
Fresh, estuarine, and salt water aquatic life from chronic toxicity impacts.
Fresh Water, Estuarine, and Salt Water Boundaries.
For any toxic substance for which no estuarine criteria appear in Regulation .03-2G, Table 1, the salt water criteria apply in estuarine waters.
Fresh water and estuarine or salt water boundaries begin at specific points for the purpose of applying the numerical toxic substance criteria for aquatic life protection. These points are:
The stream segment and all tributaries which confluence with the stream segment upstream from the boundaries specified in §B(3) of this regulation are assumed to be fresh water.

Except for Sub-Basin 02-13-01—Coastal Area, the stream segment and all tributaries which confluence with the stream segment downstream from the boundaries specified in §B(3) of this regulation are assumed to be estuarine water.

In Sub-Basin 02-13-01—Coastal Area, the stream segment and all tributaries which confluence with the stream segment downstream from the boundaries specified in §B(3) of this regulation are assumed to be salt water.
Tributary headwaters. Since the headwaters of some tributaries to stream segments designated as estuarine or salt water may be fresh, the Department may:
Require the discharger to provide site specific salinity measurements or accept site specific salinity measurements provided voluntarily by the applicant; and
Review the information provided in §B(2)(d)(i) of this regulation, and determine that the area is more appropriately designated as fresh water.
For the purpose of applying numerical toxic substance criteria, the following are designated as the boundaries between fresh waters and estuarine or salt waters:
Lower Susquehanna River Area (Sub-Basin 02-12-02)—All waters are fresh waters.
Coastal Area (Sub-Basin 02-13-01) boundaries are:
Bishopville Prong—State boat ramp at Daye Road;
Birch Branch—Route 113;
Middle Branch—Route 113;
Church Branch—Route 113;
Turville Creek—Route 589;
Ayer Creek—Route 376;
Newport Creek—Hayes Landing Road; and
Poplartown Creek—Beaverdam Creek Road.
Pocomoke River Area (Sub-Basin 02-13-02) boundaries are:
Pocomoke River—A line connecting the mouth of Bullbegger Creek and the east entrance of Fair Hill Channel; and
Manokin River—Sharps Point.
Nanticoke River Area (Sub-Basin 02-13-03) boundaries are:
Nanticoke River—A line connecting Newfoundland Point and Hat Crown Point (includes Marshyhope Creek);
Wicomico River—A line connecting Pine Beach and Holland Point;
Blackwater River—Mouth at Snake Island; and
Transquaking River—Mouth at Fishing Bay.
Choptank River Area (Sub-Basin 02-13-04) boundary is a line connecting Bow Knee Point and Wrights Wharf.
Chester River Area (Sub-Basin 02-13-05) boundaries are:
Chester River—A line connecting Piney Grove and Primrose Point;
Grays Inn Creek—A line crossing the creek at Cherry Tree Point;
Herringtown Creek—All waters are fresh;
West Fork Langford Creek—A line crossing creek at Fox Point;
East Fork Langford Creek—A line connecting Piney Point and Longmarsh Point;
Philip Creek—All waters are fresh;
Reed Creek—Tilghmans Neck Road;
Corsica Creek—A line crossing the creek at Jacobs Nose;
Emory Creek—All waters are estuarine water; and
All tributaries to the Chester River upstream from Deep Point.
Elk River Area (Sub-Basin 02-13-06)—All waters are fresh water.
Bush River Area (Sub-Basin 02-13-07)—All waters are fresh water.
Gunpowder River Area (Sub-Basin 02-13-08)—All waters are fresh water.
Patapsco River Area (Sub-Basin 02-13-09) boundaries are:
Patapsco River—A line connecting Lazaretto Point and the southern terminus of the Baltimore Harbor Tunnel; and
Back River—a line connecting Rocky Point and Cuckhold Point.
West Chesapeake Bay Area (Sub-Basin 02-13-09) boundaries are:
Severn River—Bridge on State Highway 3;
All tributaries to the Severn River upstream from MD Route 648;
Magothy River—A line connecting Henderson Point and Pea Patch Point;
All tributaries to the Magothy River are fresh water; and
South River—A line drawn due north from Beards Point.
Patuxent River Area (Sub-Basin 02-13-11) boundary is a line connecting Chalk Point and God's Grace Point.
Lower Potomac River Area (Sub-Basin 02-14-01) boundaries are:
Potomac River—A line connecting Upper Cedar Point and Chotank Creek; and
All Maryland tributaries of the Potomac River upstream from St. Catherine Island are fresh water.
Washington Metropolitan Area (Sub-Basin 02-14-02)—All waters are fresh water.
Middle Potomac River Area (Sub-Basin 02-14-03)—All waters are fresh water.
Upper Potomac River Area (Sub-Basin 02-14-05)—All waters are fresh water.
North Branch Potomac River Area (Sub-Basin 02-14-10)—All waters are fresh water.
Youghiogheny River Area (Sub-Basin 05-02-02)—All waters are fresh water.
Conewago Creek Area (Sub-Basin 02-05-03)—All waters are fresh water.

Chesapeake Bay Proper (Sub-Basin 02-13-99) boundary is a line connecting Booby Point (39.284206 north latitude, -76.381400 west longitude) with Handy's Point (39.291944 north latitude, -76.181388 west longitude).

section.heading: Numerical Criteria for Toxic Substances in Surface Waters.

para.text: Numerical toxic substance criteria shall be applied:
In intermittent streams, at the end of the discharge pipe; and
In all other water bodies, at the edge of the mixing zones determined in accordance with Regulation .05C—E of this chapter.
Acceptable laboratory methods for the detection and measurement of toxic substances shall be specified by the Department.
Site-specific numerical toxic substance criteria may be developed on a site-specific basis. A person who wishes to develop a site-specific numerical toxic substance criterion shall:
Do so in accordance with a scientifically defensible methodology approved by the Department; and
Notify the Department of their intent not later than the time specified in COMAR 26.08.04.01-1.
The toxicity of certain substances in Tables 1 and 6 of §G of this regulation is increased or decreased by hardness or pH. For these toxic substances:
The Department may:
Require the discharger to provide site-specific measurements; or
Recalculate the aquatic life criteria based on available water quality data.
The permittee may voluntarily provide site-specific information for the recalculation of the criteria. It is within the Department's discretion to determine the weight given this information.
After reviewing the information provided in §D(1) or (2), the Department shall determine if one or more of these criteria should be modified at a particular location.

For calculation of site-specific copper criteria, a discharger may use the Biotic Ligand Model in accordance with "Aquatic Life Ambient Freshwater Quality Criteria-Copper 2007 Revision (EPA-822-R-07-001, February 2007)" which is incorporated by reference.
In those cases where numerical toxic substance criteria for aquatic life protection and protection of human health both apply, the most restrictive of the criteria shall be used.

Acute and chronic numeric toxic substance criteria for fresh, estuarine, and salt water aquatic life protection and for human health protection are shown in Tables 1—6 of §G. For the instream application of the acute and chronic criteria for the protection of aquatic life in Tables 1—6 of §G of this regulation:

The metals shall be measured as dissolved metal or as biologically available equivalence and may be translated to total recoverable measurements for waste load allocation to derive discharge permit limits using the procedures for the biological translator or chemical translator described in COMAR 26.08.04;

The organic substances shall be measured directly or as biologically available equivalence and may be translated for waste load allocation to derive discharge permit limits using the procedures for the biological translator described in COMAR 26.08.04; and
Cyanide shall be measured as either free cyanide or cyanide amenable to chlorination.

Acute Numeric Toxic Substance Criteria for Ammonia for the Protection of Fresh Water Aquatic Life.

The use of Tables 3 and 4 requires documentation acceptable to the Department of the absence of freshwater mussels using the methods outlined in the document “Procedures for Applying the Mussel-Absent Ammonia Criteria to Maryland Surface Waters”, which is incorporated by reference.
Presence of Salmonid Fish. In Class III, III-P, IV, and IV-P waters, the concentration of total ammonia (in milligrams of nitrogen per liter) may not exceed the acute criterion listed in Table 1.
Absence of Salmonid Fish. In Class I and I-P waters, the concentration of total ammonia (in milligrams of nitrogen per liter) may not exceed the acute criterion listed in Table 2.

Presence of Salmonid Fish and Absence of Freshwater Mussels. In Class III, III-P, IV, and IV-P waters, the concentration of total ammonia (in milligrams of nitrogen per liter) may not exceed the acute criterion listed in Table 3.

Absence of Salmonid Fish and Absence of Freshwater Mussels. In Class I and I-P waters, the concentration of total ammonia (in milligrams of nitrogen per liter) may not exceed the acute criterion listed in Table 4.

Averaging Period. The concentration of total ammonia nitrogen (in milligrams of nitrogen per liter) expressed as a 30-day average may not exceed the chronic criterion listed in Tables 1, 2 or 3.
The use of Table 3 requires documentation acceptable to the Department of the absence of fish early life stages.

The use of Table 2 or 3 requires documentation acceptable to the Department of the absence of freshwater mussels using the methods outlined in the document Procedures for Applying Mussel-Absent Ammonia Criteria to Maryland Surface Waters.
In addition, the highest 4-day average within the 30-day period may not exceed 2½ times the chronic criterion.

para.text: Saltwater and Estuarine Acute Criteria for Ammonia. Acute numeric toxic substance criteria for ammonia to protect marine and estuarine life are shown in Table 1. In estuarine and saltwaters, the concentration of total ammonia (in milligrams/liter) may not exceed the acute criterion listed in Table 1. Milligrams per liter total ammonia in saltwater (Table 1) may be converted to milligrams of ammonia nitrogen per liter (as used in §§H and I of this regulation) by multiplying the criteria values in Table 1 by 14/17 (or 0.82353) to result in total ammonia nitrogen.

Averaging Period. The concentration of total ammonia (in milligrams/liter) expressed as a 30-day average may not exceed the chronic criterion listed in Table 1.

Milligrams per liter total ammonia in saltwater (Table 1) may be converted to milligrams of ammonia nitrogen per liter (as used in §§H and I of this regulation) by multiplying the criteria values in Table 1 by 14/17 (or 0.82353) to result in total ammonia nitrogen.
