para.text: Discharge Approval Required.

Any discharge or disposal of waters or wastewaters into the underground waters of the State requires the approval of the Department. The approval, if granted, will contain limitations and requirements deemed necessary by the Department to protect the public health and welfare and to prevent pollution of ground and surface waters.
A separate State discharge permit is required for:
Wastewater effluents disposed of by means of spray or other land treatment or application systems;
Ground water recharge systems;
Discharge of leachate from a landfill to surface or ground waters except as specified in §A(3)(a); and
Other subsurface disposal systems not specifically exempted in this regulation.

para.aftertext: (Agency note: A separate State discharge permit is a discharge permit issued to an individual discharger or point source. A general permit is a State discharge permit issued to a class of dischargers pursuant to COMAR 26.08.04.08.)

para.text: A separate State discharge permit is not required for:
Landfills designed to achieve natural attenuation of leachate and permitted under Environment Article, §9-204 or 9-224, unless there is a discharge of leachate to surface waters of the State;
Subsurface sewage disposal systems using soil absorption and permitted by the Department under Environment Article, Title 9, Subtitle 5, Annotated Code of Maryland, and COMAR 26.04.02;

Sewage sludge composting or disposal operations permitted by the Department under Environment Article, Title 9, Subtitle 2, Part III, Annotated Code of Maryland, unless there is a direct discharge of wastewater to surface waters of the State; and
Other subsurface disposal systems permitted by the Department under the provisions of COMAR 26.08.04.08.
An Underground Injection Permit issued under COMAR 26.08.07 also constitutes a discharge permit under this regulation.

The land application of food processing wastewater is exempt from the requirement to obtain a State discharge permit if the wastewater meets the Maryland Department of Agriculture (MDA) State Chemist Office requirements for registration as a soil conditioner, subject to the following conditions and exceptions:

MDA notifies the Department that a determination has been made that the wastewater meets the requirements for registration as a soil conditioner. If the Department has not responded within 45 days of the notification, the determination made by MDA shall be considered accepted and the applicant shall be exempt from obtaining a State discharge permit. If the Department verifies or rejects MDA’s State Chemist determination within 45 days of the notification, the Department may still require a State discharge permit.

The applicant continues to perform any necessary actions to ensure that the wastewater meets the requirements for registration as a soil conditioner, and complies with the COMAR 15.20.04—15.20.08, which includes the applicant’s obligation to obtain and comply with a Nutrient Management Plan governing the application of the wastewater.

Department representatives upon presentation of credentials are allowed at reasonable times to enter premises to inspect any wastewater collection, treatment, land application records and practices, and food processing operation records.

An application for renewal of the exemption set forth herein must be submitted to MDA within 5 years of the exemption date from obtaining a State discharge permit. The requirements of this subsection apply for the renewal process.
The Department may deny the permit exemption during the 45 day period or at any time choose to revoke a permit exemption provided under this section.

Aquifer Types Identified. For the purpose of controlling the pollution of the ground waters of the State, the Department of the Environment has identified three aquifer types and has established standards for ground water quality, as follows:

Type I aquifer means an aquifer having a transmissivity greater than 1,000 gallons/day/foot and a permeability greater than 100 gallons/day/square foot. In addition, the total dissolved solids concentration for natural water in each aquifer shall be less than 500 milligrams/liter.
Type II aquifer means an aquifer having either:

A transmissivity greater than 10,000 gallons/day/foot, a permeability greater than 100 gallons/day/square foot and natural water with a total dissolved solids concentration of between 500 and 6,000 milligrams/liter; or

A transmissivity between 1,000 and 10,000 gallons/day/foot, a permeability greater than 100 gallons/day/square foot and natural water with a total dissolved solids concentration of between 500 and 1,500 milligrams/liter.
Type III aquifer means all aquifers other than Type I and Type II aquifers.

Discharge Quality Criteria. The following criteria apply outside of designated mixing zones (for the purpose of this section, the term "mixing zone" means an area or volume established by the Department for the mixing of ambient ground water with waters or wastewaters, or both, discharged as authorized by the Department):
For Type I Aquifers. The characteristics or constituents of waters may not exceed primary or secondary standards for drinking water as adopted by the Department of the Environment in COMAR 26.04.01.

For Type II Aquifers. The characteristics or constituents of waters after treatment by commercially available home water treatment or softening systems may not exceed primary or secondary standards for drinking water, except for total dissolved solids, as adopted by the Department of the Environment in COMAR 26.04.01 and §B(2) of this regulation.
For Type III Aquifers. The characteristics or constituents of waters shall be such that they do not meet Type I or Type II quality criteria.
Guidelines for Discharge to Ground Waters.

Land disposal of municipal wastewater or wastewater with similar characteristics shall follow the Department of the Environment's "Guidelines for Land Application/Reuse of Treated Municipal Wastewaters" MDE-WMA-001-04/10, which is incorporated by reference.
Discharges to a ground water aquifer of specific classification may not result in pollution of an aquifer possessing higher quality criteria.

Discharges to ground water may not result in degradation of ground waters below the criteria established in §C, outside a mixing zone specified in a State discharge permit, general permit, or other permit issued by the Department of the Environment.

Dischargers or potential dischargers to ground waters may be required to monitor ground or surface waters, or both, in a manner and frequency and at locations specified by the Department of the Environment and to periodically submit the results of these activities.
As provided in COMAR 26.13.05.18, the underground injection of hazardous wastes is prohibited.
General.

The Federal Act prohibits the issuance of a federal permit or license to conduct any activity which may result in any discharge to navigable waters unless the applicant provides a certification from this State that the activity does not violate State water quality standards or limitations. This regulation establishes the procedures under which this certification will be issued.
Discharges permitted by the Department under the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System are certified by the Department.
Application for a Water Quality Certification.
An applicant for certification shall submit to the Department an application which includes:
Name and address of the applicant.
A description of the facility or activity.
A description of any discharge which may result from the conduct of any activity including:
Biological, chemical, thermal or other characteristics of the potential discharge; and
The location or locations at which any discharge may enter navigable waters.
A description, if applicable, of the function and operation of any equipment or facilities to treat any discharge and the degree of treatment to be attained.
The date on which the activity will begin or end, if known, and the date or dates on which any discharge may occur.
A description, if applicable, of the methods proposed or employed to monitor the quality and characteristics of any discharge.

Any other information the Department determines is necessary for evaluation of the impact of the activity on water quality. This may include quantitative analysis to demonstrate that the proposed activity may not violate State water quality standards.
Discharges to Outstanding National Resource Waters (ONRW) will be certified only if:
There is minimal adverse environmental impact;
The discharges will not impair the water quality necessary to maintain the exceptional biological resource of the ONRW; and
All practical actions have been taken to avoid impacts.

By agreement with either federal or State agencies in order to facilitate the certification process, the Department may develop a joint application for a federal license or permit and State water quality certification.
Public Notice.
The Department shall provide public notice of each application for certification.
The public notice shall:
Give a brief description of the proposed activity;
Provide instructions for submission of written comments; and
Specify the expiration date for the opportunity to comment.
The public notice may be given by:
Joint notice with the federal permitting agency;
Joint notice with other State agencies; or
Selected mailings to State, county, or municipal authorities and other parties known to be interested in the matter.
Determination of Need for Public Hearing. The Department may hold a public hearing before issuing any water quality certification if:
The Department determines the activity requiring certification is of broad, general interest; or
The application for certification generated substantial public interest as indicated by written comments concerning water quality issues.
Issuance of Certification.

Certification Issuance. If the Department determines the proposed activities will not cause a violation of applicable State water quality standards, the Department shall issue the water quality certification.
Applicant Responsibilities.
Issuance of water quality certification does not relieve the applicant of his responsibility to comply at all times with federal and State law.
The applicant shall:
Obtain the State water quality certification before the conduct of any activity requiring the federal permit;
Comply with all conditions of the State water quality certification to assure achievement of State water quality standards.
Emergency Procedures. The Department:

May issue an emergency water quality certification in those cases when the Department determines that an unacceptable threat to human life, water quality, or aquatic resources may occur or in those cases when a severe loss of property may result before a certification can be issued in accordance with procedures specified in §C of this regulation;

Shall issue a notice stating its action and the reasons for the action in accordance with the requirements of §C of this regulation, not later than 10 days following the issuance of the emergency certification;
Shall incorporate in the emergency certification all standards and criteria normally applied to the specific type of project authorized by the emergency certification.
Procedures for Public Hearing.
Notice of Public Hearing. The notice of public hearing shall:
Include a brief description of the project;
Include information concerning the date, time, and location of the public hearing;
Include a brief description of the nature of the written comments received; and
Be published in the Maryland Register at least 45 days before the hearing.
Public Hearing.
An interested person shall be given an opportunity to present evidence for or against the granting of water quality certification at the public hearing.
Written comments shall be received by the Department by the date of the public hearing, unless the comment period is specifically extended at the hearing.
Final Determination. After the closing date for receipt of written comments and after any public hearing the Department shall:
Consider the testimony and other information presented;
Prepare a written decision; and
Publish the decision in the Maryland Register.
Appeal of Final Decision.
A person aggrieved by the Department's decision concerning a water quality certification may appeal the decision of the Department. The appeal shall:
Be filed within 30 days of the publication of the final decision with the hearing office; and
Specify, in writing, the reason why the final determination should be reconsidered.
A further appeal shall be in accordance with the applicable provisions of State Government Article, §10-201 et seq., Annotated Code of Maryland.
General Certification.
The Department may issue a general water quality certification for a class of activities requiring any federal license or permit.
A general certification shall authorize all activities that meet the class description.

In unique circumstances not considered in the issuance of the general certification, the Department may require issuance of an individual water quality certification for an activity that could be regulated under a general certification.
General Certification Issuance and Renewal.
If the Department determines to adopt a general certification for a specific class of activities, the Department shall prepare a fact sheet:
Describing the class of activities to be included; and
Outlining the proposed conditions and limitations of the general certification.
Notice of Intent to Adopt General Certification.
The Department shall prepare a public notice which includes:
A brief description of the general and special conditions which are proposed to be included in the general certification.
Provisions for examination by interested parties of the draft permit and other information related to the preliminary determination made by the Department.

A request for written comments concerning the general permit and a statement that a public hearing may be held if significant written public comment concerning the application is received by the Department.
Instructions for submission of written comments.
The deadline specified for the submission of written comments. The deadline shall be at least 30 days from the date of publication of notice in the Maryland Register.
The Department shall publish the notice in the Maryland Register. A copy of the notice shall be sent to:
Local health officers;
Other interested State and local agencies; and
Any person requesting to be notified.
Public Hearings.
A public hearing shall be held and a notice of the public hearing shall be prepared and distributed if:
There is significant public comment concerning the tentative determination to issue a general certification; or
The Department determines that a public hearing is necessary.
The notice of public hearing shall be prepared and published in accordance with §F of this regulation.
The public hearing shall be conducted in accordance with the procedure outlined in §F of this regulation.

Appeal of Final Decision. A person aggrieved by the Department's decision concerning a general water quality certification may appeal the decision of the Department. The appeal shall be in accordance with §F(4) of this regulation.
Applicant's Responsibility. General certification of any activity does not relieve the applicant of his responsibility to comply at all times with federal and State laws.
General Water Quality Certification (GWQC) for Marsh Creation Projects.
Scope of Activity.
Definition. Marsh creation projects are defined as the vegetative stabilization of tidal shorelines and nontidal stream banks that are subject to erosion.
Exception. The projects certified by this GWQC do not include marshes created for storm water management purposes.
Marsh Creation. The creation of marshes includes the following activities:
The placement of fill material such as earth or sand;
The construction of stone containment structures;
The grading of banks; and
The planting of Spartina alterniflora, Spartina patens, or other species acceptable to the Department.

Certification. A federally permitted marsh creation project which meets the conditions of this GWQC is authorized under §401 of the Clean Water Act (33 U.S.C. 1341 (1987)), provided that other applicable federal, State, and local laws and regulations are satisfied.
Design Specifications.
The stabilization activity shall be determined to be necessary for the prevention of erosion on tidal shorelines or nontidal stream banks.
The placement of fill material authorized by this GWQC shall be limited to less than an average of 2 cubic yards of material per running foot placed within waters of the State.
The project is a single and complete project.
The applicant, in planning the project, shall comply with seasonal limitations applied to the construction phase for the protection of important aquatic species.
Construction Specifications.
Material may not be placed in excess of the minimum needed for erosion protection. All temporary fills shall be removed in their entirety on or before the completion of construction.
Material may not be placed in any location or in any manner so as to impair surface or subsurface water flow into or out of any wetland area.
Placement of fill material in existing vegetated wetlands shall be minimized to the greatest extent possible.

Only clean material free of waste metal products, organic material, unsightly debris, toxic substances in toxic amounts, or any other deleterious substance shall be placed. The fill material to be placed shall include clean earth fill, sand, and stone only.
Discharges in spawning areas during spawning seasons of important aquatic species shall be avoided.
Placement of fill material may not restrict or impede the movement of aquatic species indigenous to the waters or cause the relocation of the water.
Placement of fill material into breeding areas for migratory waterfowl shall be avoided.
Heavy equipment working in wetlands shall be placed on mats, or suitably designed to prevent damage to the wetlands.
Applicant's Responsibility.
This GWQC does not relieve the applicant of the responsibility for obtaining any other approvals, licenses, or permits in accordance with federal and State laws or regulations, or local ordinances.
This GWQC does not authorize the beginning of any proposed work in the absence of necessary approvals, licenses, or permits.
The applicant is required to comply with all conditions of this general certification.
Right of Inspection.
Reliance on this GWQC by the applicant or his agent constitutes permission to inspect at any time the operations and records for any project conducted under the authority of this GWQC.
Failure to comply with the conditions of this GWQC shall constitute reason for suspension or revocation of the applicant's use of this GWQC.
Legal proceedings may be instituted against the alleged violator in accordance with Health-General Article, §2-207, and State Government Article, §§10-201 et seq., Annotated Code of Maryland.
General Water Quality Certification (GWQC) for the Installation of Utility Lines.
Scope of Activity.

Definition. Utility lines are defined as any pipe, cable, or wire for the conveyance of public water or public sewer, natural gas, or the transmission of electrical, radio, or telecommunications service.
Exceptions.

Utility lines do not include intake and outfall structures or any pipe and pipeline used to transport any gaseous, liquid, or slurry substance except as associated with natural gas, water, and sewage lines.
Blasting, as a construction method, is not authorized by this GWQC.
Installation of gas pipe lines larger than 12 inches in diameter is not authorized by this GWQC.
Installation. The installation of utility lines includes the following activities:
The trenching, jetting, jackhammering, or plowing of wetlands or waterways;
The laying of a pipe, cable, or wire;
The backfilling of the excavated trench containing the pipe, cable, or wire;
The placement of riprap; and
The vegetative stabilization of wetland areas which have been disturbed.

Certification. A federally permitted utility line installation which meets the conditions of this GWQC is authorized under §401 of the Clean Water Act (33 U.S.C. 1341 (1987)), provided that other applicable federal, State and local laws and regulations are satisfied.
Design Specifications.
The applicant, in planning the project, shall comply with seasonal limitations applied to the construction phase for the protection of important aquatic species.
The post-construction bottom contours of waters and elevations of wetlands shall be the same as original contours and elevations.

Disturbances of wetlands and waterways shall be avoided or minimized through the use of other practical alternatives such as designing the utility line in a proposed or existing roadway or using an existing right-of-way.
Construction Specifications.
Excess material shall be removed to an upland disposal area identified on the plan submitted for approval.
Temporary fill materials shall be removed in their entirety on or before the completion of construction.
Material may not be placed in any location or in any manner so as to impair surface or subsurface water flow into or out of any wetland area.

If backfill material is obtained from sources other than the originally excavated material, it shall be clean material, free of waste metal products, organic material, unsightly debris, toxic substances in toxic amounts, or any other deleterious substance.
Permanent work may not:
Restrict or impede the movement of aquatic species indigenous to the waters;
Restrict or impede the passage of normal or expected high flows;
Cause the relocation of the water; or
Cause the impoundment of water.
To protect important aquatic species, in-stream work is prohibited as determined by the use designation of the stream, as follows:
Class I and Class I-P Waters. In-stream work may not be conducted during the period March 1 through June 15, inclusive, during any year.
Class II Waters. In-stream work may not be conducted during the period June 1 through September 30 or December 16 through March 14, inclusive, during any year.
Class III and Class III-P Waters. In-stream work may not be conducted during the period October 1 through April 30, inclusive, during any year.
Class IV and Class IV-P Waters. In-stream work may not be conducted during the period March 1 through May 31, inclusive, during any year.
Disturbances in breeding areas for migratory waterfowl shall be avoided.
Heavy equipment working in wetlands shall be placed on mats or suitably designed to prevent damage to the wetland.
The applicant shall obtain and comply with a State or locally approved sediment control plan. The following apply:
This plan shall be on site during all phases of construction;
Sediment bearing waters may not be discharged to the receiving waterway except as provided in the approved sediment control plan;
Discharges of sediment bearing water may not cause violations of the applicable State water quality standards.
Applicant's Responsibility.
This GWQC does not relieve the applicant of the responsibility for obtaining any other approvals, licenses, or permits in accordance with federal and State law or regulation, or local ordinance.
This GWQC does not authorize the beginning of any proposed work in the absence of necessary approvals, licenses, or permits.
The applicant is required to comply with all conditions of the GWQC.
The applicant is required to maintain all utility installations constructed under the authority of this GWQC. All utility maintenance is subject to the conditions of this GWQC.
Right of Inspection.
Reliance on this GWQC by the applicant or his agent constitutes permission to inspect at any time the operations and records for any project conducted under the authority of this GWQC.
Failure to comply with the conditions of this GWQC shall constitute reason for suspension or revocation of the applicant's use of this GWQC.
Legal proceedings may be instituted against the alleged violator in accordance with Health-General Article, §2-207, and State Government Article, §§10-201 et seq., Annotated Code of Maryland.

section.heading: General Water Quality Certification (GWQC) for the Construction of Bulkheads.

para.text: Scope of Activity.
Definition. "Bulkheads" means the structural stabilization of tidal and nontidal shorelines that are subject to erosion.
Exceptions.

Bulkheads authorized by this GWQC do not include structures which allow passage of a discharge pipe of any kind, such as storm water outfalls and those outfalls regulated under State discharge permits.
Riprap revetments are not authorized by this GWQC.
Bulkhead Construction. The construction of bulkheads includes the following activities:
Driving of piles;
Placement of a timber, aluminum, or steel vertical shoreline erosion control structure;
Placement of a gabion wall;
Placement of backfill behind the structure; and
Placement of riprap at the channelward toe of the structure.

Certification. A federally permitted bulkhead project which meets the conditions of the GWQC is authorized under §401 of the Federal Act provided that other applicable federal, State, and local laws and regulations are satisfied.
Design Specifications.
The stabilization activity shall be necessary for the prevention of erosion on tidal shorelines or nontidal stream banks.
The placement of fill material authorized by this GWQC shall be limited to an average of 1 cubic yard of material per running foot placed within waters of the State.
The project shall be a single and complete project.
The project shall be limited to 500 feet in length.
Construction Specifications.
The vertical structure shall be constructed in its entirety before the discharge of backfill material.
Material may not be placed in excess of the minimum needed for erosion protection.
Excess material shall be removed to an upland site identified on the plan submitted for the federal permit.
Temporary fills shall be removed in their entirety on or before the completion of construction.
Material may not be placed in any location or in any manner so as to impair surface or subsurface water flow into or out of any wetland area.

Placement of fill material in existing vegetated wetlands shall be minimized to the greatest extent possible. Bulkheads shall be placed landward of existing marsh vegetation. An area which contains more than 10 percent vegetated wetlands may not be filled.

Where the vertical structure is inundated by 2 feet or greater depths of water at the mean high water tide, stone riprap shall be placed at the toe of the structure to protect the structure from wave and tide action and to prevent the disturbance and transport of sediment to waters of the State, which may occur as a result of the scouring actions of wave and tide. Gabion walls are exempted from this requirement.
Only clean material free of waste metal products, organic material, unsightly debris, toxic material, or any other deleterious substance shall be placed as backfill.
The applicant shall obtain and comply with a State or locally approved sediment control plan when disturbing or placing greater than 100 cubic yards of earth or backfill.
Work in the waterway in spawning areas during spawning seasons of important aquatic species is prohibited.
Placement of fill material may not restrict or impede the movement of aquatic species indigenous to the waters, or cause the relocation of the waters.
Disturbances in breeding areas for migratory waterfowl shall be avoided.
Heavy equipment working in wetlands shall be placed on mats, or suitably designed to prevent damage to the wetlands.
Applicant's Responsibility.
This GWQC does not:
Relieve the applicant of the responsibility for obtaining any other approvals, licenses, or permits in accordance with federal and State laws or regulation, or local ordinances;
Authorize the beginning of any proposed work in the absence of necessary approvals, licenses, or permits.
The applicant shall comply with all conditions of this general certification.
Right of Inspection and Department Enforcement.

Reliance on this GWQC by the applicant or the applicant's agent constitutes permission to the Department to inspect at any time the operations and records for any project constructed under the authority of this GWQC.

An activity is authorized by the GWQC as long as compliance with the conditions of the GWQC is maintained. Upon failure to comply with the conditions of this GWQC, the applicant is required to apply for an individual water quality certification.
Legal proceedings may be instituted against an alleged violator in accordance with the provisions of the Environment Article and State Government Article, Annotated Code of Maryland.

section.heading: General Water Quality Certification (GWQC) for the Placement of Riprap for Shore Protection.

para.text: Scope of Activity.
Definition. Riprap revetments are defined as:
A facing of loose stone, brick, or masonry placed for the purpose of stabilizing tidal and nontidal shorelines that are subject to erosion; and
Being constructed with materials of suitable size and weight to prevent their transport into the waterway.
Exceptions.

Riprap revetments authorized by the GWQC do not include structures which allow passage of a discharge pipe of any kind, such as storm water outfalls and those outfalls regulated under State discharge permits.
Materials authorized for placement may not include asphalt, waste metal products, organic materials, unsightly debris, toxic material, or any other deleterious substance.
Revetments may not be constructed to create fastland.
Construction of Revetments. The construction of revetments includes the following activities:
Excavation;
Placement of filter cloth or other base;
Stabilization of disturbed slopes by seeding or planting;
Placement of loose or broken stone;
Placement of aggregate or concrete mix;
Placement of concrete and block;
Pouring of concrete; and
Placement of backfill.

Certification. A federally permitted placement of riprap which meets the conditions of the GWQC is authorized under §401 of the Federal Act, provided that other applicable federal, State, and local laws and regulations are satisfied.
Design Specifications.
The stabilization activity shall be necessary for the prevention of erosion on tidal or nontidal shorelines.
The placement of fill material authorized by the GWQC shall be limited to the minimum needed for erosion protection.
The project shall be a single and complete project.
Construction Specifications.
Material may not be placed in excess of the minimum needed for erosion protection.
Excess material shall be removed to an upland site identified on the plan submitted for the federal permit.
Temporary fills shall be removed in their entirety on or before the completion of construction.
Material may not be placed in any location or in any manner so as to impair surface water flow into or out of any wetland area.

Placement of fill material in existing vegetated wetlands shall be minimized to the greatest extent possible. Riprap revetments shall be placed landward of existing marsh vegetation. An area which contains more than 10 percent vegetated wetlands may not be filled.
The maximum slope of riprap revetments may not exceed 2:1.
The maximum encroachment of riprap revetments may not extend more than 10 feet channelward of the mean high water shoreline.
Riprap revetments shall be constructed on a base of filter cloth.
The applicant shall obtain and comply with a State or locally approved sediment control plan when disturbing or placing greater than 100 cubic yards of earth or backfill.
Work in the waterway in spawning areas during spawning seasons of important aquatic species is prohibited.
Placement of fill material may not restrict or impede the movement of aquatic species indigenous to the waters or cause the relocation of the waters.
Disturbances in breeding areas for migratory waterfowl shall be avoided.
Heavy equipment working in wetlands shall be placed on mats, or suitably designed to prevent damage to the wetlands.
Applicant's Responsibility.
This GWQC does not relieve the applicant of the responsibility for obtaining any other approvals, licenses, or permits in accordance with federal and State laws or regulation, or local ordinances.
This GWQC does not authorize the beginning of any proposed work in the absence of necessary approvals, licenses, or permits.
The applicant shall comply with all conditions of this general certification.
Right of Inspection and Department Enforcement.

Reliance on this GWQC by the applicant or the applicant's agent constitutes permission to the Department to inspect at any time the operations and records for any project constructed under the authority of this GWQC.

An activity is authorized by the GWQC as long as compliance with the conditions of the GWQC is maintained. Upon failure to comply with the conditions of this GWQC, the applicant is required to apply for an individual water quality certification.
Legal proceedings may be instituted against the alleged violator in accordance with the provisions of the Environment Article and State Government Article, Annotated Code of Maryland.
